I know many parents who tell me their places of work have given up on them and they are unable to take any more days off. Those parents then have their own journeys whereby they are almost being bullied by their employers because they are taking time off and perhaps are working less hard than they were previously. It is difficult. I am glad that Professor MacLachlan mentioned educational engagement
column9: which is crucial. That is the missing link here. The CDNT network is there but it must be redirected towards schools around the country. Therapists must be in the schools because parents cannot be dragging their kids to therapy appointments. Many parents do not have the means or wherewithal to do so. It is unfair. For a child from a family at a social disadvantage
column10: it is not going to be a priority to bring that child to an appointment with an occupational therapist or a speech and language therapist. We have a super education system. It is ingrained in us that people need to bring their children to school. Therapies must be delivered in a school setting. Our guests much push for that delivery. There is a one third vacancy rate. I asked a few occupational therapists and speech and language therapists why they do not want to work in the HSE or the CDNTs. They told me they do not like it and they do not like the politics involved. They said they do not get much interaction with children because there is a concentration on family engagement and teaching the parents. Those young therapists want to be working directly with kids. They like the idea of working in a school-type environment. These are young women who are not motivated by money and are not going to be whipped into providing an enormous amount of hours. They would love to work in a school-type environment where they know their children and environment. The children are happier because they are not being dragged to appointments. column11: the majority of whom are women
column12: not want to work in the CDNTs? The education piece is the answer to that. We need to push therapists back into the schools via the CDNTs
column13: because that is the structure in place. It would allow therapists to have a school they know and attend. They could build up a rapport with other staff members. That is crucial. I agree with much of what my colleagues have said about AON
column14: but that is a monster in itself. My message today
column15: which our guests might pass on
column16: is that we should redirect our resources
column18: towards the schools. We are always going to have children who are not in school settings and who will have to be given therapies in the community. However

column23: a diagnosis is crucial in Ireland because a child cannot get into an early intervention class or an ASD class without a diagnosis. Nobody needs a diagnosis. The only reason a diagnosis is necessary

column26: those tools cannot be accessed without a diagnosis. The education piece is key. Diagnoses are required for early intervention

#JoanCollins	unknown-#JoanCollins-party	unknown-#JoanCollins-dob	unknown-#JoanCollins-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	139	I have been listening intently for the past hour and a half. As was said earlier on
column2: in some ways I am probably more confused than I was when I came in. This probably reflects the frustration and confusion felt by these children and their families. I do not think that after this meeting
column3: they will feel there is light at the end of the tunnel. Deputy Carroll MacNeill got to the crux of it
column4: namely
column5: staffing levels. If we do not have the staffing levels
column6: we do not have the access. A parent who wants to get his or her child assessed and then referred to therapies and for other things he or she needs because of the effects of the disability
column7: such as nappies and shoes
column8: is looking at anything from 18 to 24 months. It has not really changed. When I was elected in 2011
column9: one of the first issues raised with me involved the CHOs. I would have referred to CHO 7 a lot. This involved phenomenal early intervention waiting lists that children outgrew. Many children were involved with St. John of God and other services. The CDNTs were supposed to be the start of a change in how children were assessed and parents supported. There was a lacuna for about three months for a lot of parents between the time when they lost their services at St. John of God
column10: or whatever service provider they were with
column11: and the time when they began to deal with the CDNTs. Many parents reported to me and other Deputies that they did not find those initial CDNT assessments very helpful. They were being referred to family supports
column12: family forums and parents' support
column13: all involving what parents can do to assist their children
column14: rather than getting the direct service they needed such as speech and language therapy. Professor MacLachlan said that the WHO has referred to it as a model that other countries should use. Unless we have the staffing levels
column15: we will not be able to resolve this issue in the CDNTs
column16: in the community or in the schools. There have been issues with therapists for the past 12 years. I heard the witnesses say the HSE has an international recruitment campaign but I have seen recruitment campaigns for mental health nurses and nurses in general for the state of Victoria in Australia all around the city. The whole world seems to be scrapping over staff to fill vacancies in these areas. I am at a loss and perhaps the witnesses can direct me. Why can we not have a drive in areas such as this? I know therapists have a right to go wherever they choose after graduating but we must target these services and open up graduate courses so more people can go into these services. We also need to keep them in the country through efforts in areas like wages and conditions. I know that is not the witnesses' duty but there needs to be concentration on getting graduates into these services. I do not want to sound very pessimistic but we are talking about funding for 830 to 850 vacancies yet we are talking about only being able to recruit 100 or 150 people for CDNTs. In addition
column17: there is pressure on other areas looking for the same therapists. Do the witnesses think we should have a plan with targets and a focus on retention in respect of these services? For families facing the prospect of waiting for 18 to 24 months
column18: it is not a good place to be from the point of view of the children's supports.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	140	I will comment on some of those questions and Professor MacLachlan on other parts. We are working with our HR colleagues at the moment to progress a dedicated recruitment campaign for children's services. That includes the points I was making earlier on the work with current panels
column2: graduates and the international campaign and we have other measures that we are putting in place to incentivise staff to come and work in the children's services. It is a priority area for the HSE to focus on. A difficulty we have
column3: and it is almost the perfect storm
column4: is that there has been significant investment in the HSE in recent years and many aspects of service have been going to the same pool to draw on a similar profile of staff. The system is not producing enough of the types of staff that we need. Professor MacLachlan will have some direct experience of this. We need to be producing more graduates in Ireland to meet our need. We need more speech and language therapists and so on. We need more programmes that allow people who have a primary degree in another area to do a short conversion programme that allows them to move into a therapy role and so on. There is a range of measures that the college systems need to develop to meet the needs of the State. Moreover
column5: these are needs that are going to increase. The capacity review report of disability services has a projection of what is needed over a decade. If the level of funding identified in the capacity review report were to come over the next decade
column6: we have an indication of the type of staffing that we need. We need the system to produce those staff.  I am in no doubt of the commitment among my colleagues in the HSE
column7: including in HR
column8: that recruitment into the children's network teams is absolutely a priority area and one that we are working to encourage people to go to work in. However
column9: I say that while needing to acknowledge that we continue to compete with some other service areas that are also in urgent need of a similar profile of staff.  Will Professor MacLachlan comment on colleges?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	141	Deputy Joan Collins said that there was not light at the end of the tunnel. It is important to say that there definitely is light but the tunnel is way longer than we would like it to be. I do not think she is at all confused about things. She articulated how many interdependencies need to be addressed. Unfortunately
column2: it not one quick fix that will get us to where we want to be in a couple of years' time. It will take longer than that. Overall
column3: at HSE level there is an initiative to look at third level and design new approaches to health sector training. Specifically in the disability sector
column4: for over a year the clinical programme has been advocating that there would be a particular initiative around health and social care professions
column5: as Mr. O'Regan mentioned. For instance
column6: you can have graduate entry into occupational therapy and speech and language therapy. People can graduate fully in a two-year span on a graduate-entry masters degree. That is a very short feed-in time in health. Even investing in those professions would make a significant difference
column7: as well as the other health and social care professions. Importantly
column8: when I was trained as a clinical psychologist I was trained to work almost independently whereas now we want people to come out ready to work in an interdisciplinary way
column9: for instance
column10: to work on children's disability network teams. There needs to be a very specific initiative around disability. We have been advocating for that in the HSE's overall approach to third level to make sure that there is a strong voice around disability. It is crucial that we put out the message that there is a bright light at the end of the tunnel because if we talk down disability
column11: it will become less attractive for people to come in here. While we can in no way run away from the huge challenges we have
column12: we need to create a virtuous circle that will attract more people to train and work in this area.

column2: I have engaged with those people and we realise that they are understaffed and overworked. Some would complain about the contractual situation they are in and others might have issues with the lack of progression in their own teams. I am fully aware of that
column3: as are the majority of us here. My first question is on PDS
column4: which is probably the most contentious issue up for debate. A simple question: is it working? Maybe Mr. O'Regan could answer that.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	143	I know the Deputy wants a straight answer. column2: such as staff availability
column3: supervision
column4: career pathways. All those things become factors. We also have experience of the service working well for some children and families but it is not working for everybody.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	158	I might add to what Mr. Higgins said. column2: adult services
column3: day services and so on
column4: although there are probably some areas on which we need some further work from a policy perspective. The transfer of functions
column5: taking disability services out of the Department of Health and moving them into the Department of Children
column6: Equality
column7: Disability
column8: Integration and Youth
column9: creates the potential for a whole-of-government approach to supports for disabled people
column10: including children and adults who are autistic. That is important because
column11: at the moment
column12: the HSE is looked at to be the provider of a lot of services that would be better provided elsewhere. We provide transport services but we are not the Department of Transport
column13: and we provide housing but we are not the Department of Housing
column14: Local Government and Heritage. A system can be expected to provide only so much and that can be stretched
column15: but we now have an opportunity now to ask whether it would be better to have a whole-of-government approach and a whole-Department approach working collaboratively in the best interests of disabled people
column16: older people or whomever we are focusing on. column3: for example

column6: and I presume they have informed the Departments of Education and Further and Higher Education
column7: Research

column10: Research

column21: they were putting people onto more lists to get a proper assessment for autism or to access services
column22: which they have not been able to access

column26: because there are not enough special school settings

column3: I could not agree more. In fact
column4: I raised this at the Joint Committee on Disability Matters. That is something the Joint Committee on Disability Matters could look at because it relates to public sector employment agreements. In terms of the assessment of needs
column5: that guidance has been developed and signed off by the highest level clinical committee within the HSE. column6: that is gone now anyway because Ms Justice Siobhán Phelan found it was not compliant with the Act. In terms of what the Deputy says about diagnosis
column7: we are not in any way against the diagnosis. What we are saying is that it is not sufficient to identify a person's needs. For example
column8: in the UK
column9: every year there are 5
column10: 000 people who are classified as SWAN
column11: where SWAN stands for syndrome without a name. If one was to require everyone to have a diagnosis to have access to services
column12: those children would never have access to services. More importantly
column13: as the recent literature review I cited emphasises
column14: sometimes an overemphasis on diagnosis can detract from the need to address people's needs and can sometimes misalign resources to diagnostic categories rather than to particular needs of children. However
column15: that is not in any way undermining the importance of diagnosis
column16: both in terms of authenticating people's experience or giving them a sense of identity around their difficulties.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	164	If I may come back on one point

column7: which was only in recent weeks
column8: the pharmacist in the hospital reviewing his medication identified two medications that should not be combined and that had been prescribed by the psychiatrist attached to the residential setting. column9: if possible
column10: in the community rather than in residential settings.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	168	May I comment briefly? Obviously

column4: however
column5: residential services are covered by regulation and are inspected by HIQA. There are requirements that those in residential services have access to appropriate multidisciplinary supports. In a way
column6: therefore

column5: if someone develops a severe mental health condition or
column6: often

column11: perhaps because of the frustrations of living with autism

column1: #RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	198	Within the current setup
column2: if a person knows for definite there is a speech and language issue
column3: the assessment process stops there and then. There is a logic to that. Once the person could access services
column4: I do not think we would hear from him or her again.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	199	That is the essence of the clinical guidelines we have developed. In many cases
column2: more than one therapist will need to be involved in an assessment and it will take longer than that. Where cases have presentations that are relatively less complex
column3: it allows provision to have much shorter assessment. The idea of universal targeted and specific interventions is that for some people it is sufficient to have universal interventions. Where that is not sufficient
column4: there are more time-consuming interventions from the point of view of the service. The tiered approach means trying to get the most out of an insufficient resource.

column1: #RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	200	This is about a bespoke solution based on a child's needs.
#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	201	Yes
column2: absolutely. It is needs based and family and child centred. The outcomes are determined by the family and child.

column1: #MichealCarrigy	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-party	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-dob	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	202	Mr. Higgins was looking to get in.

#RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	203	I am well over time.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	204	The Deputy asked what we need. We need a tiered approach. Not every child needs 37 hours of assessment. It helps us to get the most of out of a stressed system
column2: but it is also the way we should be doing business. We are piloting the tiered approach to ASD assessment in our area and getting good results. We are only starting off in our implementation. It is early days and we need more data
column3: but the experience of doing it has been positive because we are using intervention as a form of assessment. We are getting back to intervention first and using the information from that as a source of observation and diagnosis in some cases. We have been surprised by how effective that has been in certain cases. It is not for every child - some children need a more complex tier of assessment. That is the direction in which we need to be going. In terms of assessment of need
column4: there is a legislative obligation that we cannot get out of
column5: but if we are giving interventions within six months the number of assessment of need referrals drops off.If we are using this tiered approach to get back to intervention first
column6: based on obvious need rather than cumbersome assessment
column7: we will be putting our resources in the right direction and clients will benefit.

column1: #MichealCarrigy	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-party	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-dob	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	205	In your opening statement
column2: you said that it is not acceptable for an individual with autism to have to wait an extended time for an assessment of needs or for supports or therapies and that is the crux of it. As I said at a meeting with representatives of CHO 8 on Friday last
column3: staffing levels within the children's disability network teams
column4: CDNTs
column5: are a disgrace. We have heard evidence from families of having to pay up to €1
column6: 800 for private assessments. We have also heard stories of people getting assessments that are not being recognised. It is not acceptable
column7: to be quite honest. I like the tiered model. That is the way forward. Having listened to the explanation of that model today
column8: I have a better understanding of it and I believe it is the way to go. There will be two more pilot areas
column9: following on from the two that have already been done. What CHO areas will those pilots take place in? I will talk about my experience with the CDNT in Longford. Last April we met the Minister of State at the Department of Health
column10: Deputy Rabbitte because there were more than 230 children waiting for an assessment of needs and more than 700 waiting for services. Our team is now worse than it was at that time. During the summer we had 3.8 whole time equivalents on the team. There was no social worker
column11: 0.8 in physiotherapy
column12: 0.5 in speech and language therapy
column13: one in occupational therapy and things were just getting worse.  A number of members have raised the issue of third level education. Who is responsible within the HSE for liaising with the Department of Further and Higher Education
column14: Research
column15: Innovation and Science? Whoever that is has not done his or her job because there is not a sufficient number of graduates coming through the third level system. There are four colleges that run occupational therapy courses in the country
column16: with around 90 professionals graduating every year. Statisticians could figure out the number of those graduates that will go into the public system and the number that will go travelling
column17: based on available data. Somebody has not done his or her job. The HSE has not engaged with the Department of Further and Higher Education
column19: Innovation and Science across all of the services
column21: occupational therapy and speech and language therapy. The therapists are not there so somebody has failed. Families and children have been failed because this work has not been done. We have more than 700 vacancies because we do not have enough qualified people coming through the system. As Deputy Casey said earlier
column22: we should know the numbers and percentages. We should know how many children are going to need services and we should have front-loaded courses at third level in order to have graduates coming through. Whoever is responsible for that within the HSE has failed and that is why we are in this situation. Reference was made to the Disability Act. What engagement has the HSE had with the Government with regard to changing that legislation vis-à-vis assessments and services? This issue was highlighted a number of times today. What engagement has taken place and is there resistance to making amendments to the Disability Act? Reference was also made earlier to family engagement and I have read about autism support workers. In my experience
column23: it is the professionals who do the family engagement but while that is happening
column24: services are not being provided for children. The family engagement should be undertaken by non-professionals or by autism support workers. They should be giving courses to parents. I have seen that in my own local area
column25: with professionals giving courses even though we have a massive shortage of such professionals and ultimately it results in fewer services being provided to children. I invite our guests to comment further on the school inclusion model
column26: which I believe is the way forward but I am a bit worried that there will be no HSE involvement in it. Do I sense a conflict with regard to the school inclusion model? As Deputy Ó Murchú said
column27: taking children out of a setting in which they are comfortable
column29: and bringing them into a clinical setting
column30: with parents having to take time off work
column31: is not ideal. I have seen the centre in my own local area and I made complaints about it when I first went into it. It was not even properly painted and was not an appropriate setting for children. The model involving the school
column33: is better. We have met the teachers' unions recently and discussed the fact that we need to change the training for teachers to enable them to work with children with autism. We should also be training the SNAs to provide some elements of therapy on a daily basis but that must be backed up by professionals coming into the schools regularly. Deputy Pádraig O'Sullivan raised the issue of professionals in special schools. Reference was made to 104 out of 136 special schools. Why were only 104 schools picked
column34: and not the full 136? Is that a manpower issue? There are lots of questions there and I invite Mr. O'Regan to respond.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	206	Thank you Chairman. Please remind me if I miss anything. Workforce planning is led by our human resources
column2: HR
column3: section but none of us here works in that area. In fairness
column4: what I would suggest is that HR would send a note to the committee. As far as I know
column5: they have made representations
column6: although they may not be adequate. Given that they are not here
column7: I will ask that they send a briefing note to the committee on what has been done. In that way the committee will at least be aware of what steps have been taken. We have raised the issue of the Disability Act at the Joint Committee on Disability Matters and the Joint Committee on Children
column8: Equality
column9: Disability
column10: Integration and Youth previously. The feedback we have received is that any review of that Act where the perception would be that it is being driven by an attempt by the HSE to wriggle out of its current legal responsibilities would be very challenging and contentious. In fairness to ourselves
column11: that is not what we are suggesting. What we are suggesting is an enhancement of the Act so that it incorporates a right to services as well as a right to assessment and that will not make it easier for us. In terms of the kinds of issues that we are already facing
column12: having a legal requirement around them does not make it any easier to implement than where we are at today but it does equalise the importance of intervention and the assessment.  The school inclusion model
column13: on which Ms O'Kelly might want to comment further
column14: was designed to focus on supporting a child to be able to access the curriculum. That was its primary focus. In some respects
column15: it had quite a narrow orientation but we know that many children that we support have needs that go beyond
column16: but also include
column17: accessing the curriculum. It is not the case that there is any tension between us or a row going on. Rather
column18: there is a debate to be had about the right direction in which to go. Our view is having a model that takes account the child in all its environments is important and that includes access to the curriculum. That does not take away from the potential for staff to work in special schools. The 104 schools versus 136 is purely a function of an agreement with Government to address the change that those schools that had access to a service prior to reconfiguration would be addressed first. I expect that at some point in time
column19: Government will engage on the other schools. To be honest
column20: adding more today will not make it deliver any faster than we are able to go at the moment but the 104 is directly related to the schools that had access to services being delivered in the school prior to reconfiguration. It was purely a function of that. Again
column21: I need to highlight that even since then the increased number of special classes and the number of children who are also accessing mainstream school has also continued to grow
column22: even in the past number of years
column23: and they are not included in that figure either. I have probably missed some questions and I am sorry.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	207	I might add something on the school inclusion model if that is okay. The Department of Education and the NCSE could answer this much better but a fundamental piece is their client in all this is the school and the school inclusion model. The service user or client is the child and the family for the clinicians. I agree with the Chairman that there should not be silos and separate streams. We need an integrated programme for children
column2: if you like
column3: be that across services within the HSE and interagency ones between the Departments of Education and Health. There is a universal level the school inclusion model looked at for building the capacity of teachers. That could fit so well within the NCSE. It has huge resources on CPD and education for our staff and for teachers. If you thought of a child
column4: you would think of bundles of care
column5: so it is absolutely about inclusion in school and education
column6: self-care in the home environment and building the capacity to be able to participate in their local community and transition. Transitioning is huge for children. Let us think of the move from the junior phase in senior infants up into first class
column7: from fifth to sixth class and then from sixth class to first year and doing that work. That is where bundles of care in the form of CDNTs providing transitional work come in. They assist with summer programmes for children to help them transition. Reaching into the school with those bundles provides a much more enhanced experience for the child. Does that make sense?

column1: #MichealCarrigy	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-party	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-dob	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	208	Yes. I wrote down a question I was going to ask on the summer programme. It is an issue we put quite a strong focus on as a committee because of the lack of schools
column2: especially special schools
column3: providing the programme. In some of our discussions we have spoken about an occupational therapy programme and therapists going in
column4: or perhaps third- or fourth-year students in the colleges being employed for the summer to build up that relationship. They would get experience of working in the summer programme and give extra services to kids and families when they need it. What is Ms O'Kelly's view on that?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	209	From our experience on the school inclusion model
column2: we felt therapists working on the model and in the schools could add value along the way. Many of our services in primary care and in the disability sector such as the CDNTs provide these summer camps. One of our big pieces was the hope the therapists who were employed on the school inclusion model would do the thing and work with their primary care and CDNT colleagues
column3: so again to build that integration and robustness around the child. Then knowledge is being brought to wherever the child is transitioning to next because that leap into secondary school and the leap into the senior cycle is so enormous for children. I certainly am an advocate of that. Various agencies have tried it. The Central Remedial Clinic used to run summer camps. The HSE
column4: as I said
column5: runs summer camps. That is what we call them because it is normalised. Kids are used to going to summer camp but it helps with the continuity.

column1: #MichealCarrigy	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-party	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-dob	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	210	Does Professor MacLachlann have anything to add?

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	211	I might respond to a couple of questions. The Chairman asked which CHOs were involved in the next phase. Ms O'Kelly's organisation
column2: CHO 7
column3: is one of them and we are just finalising arrangements with CHO 4. I agree with everything Mr. O'Regan said regarding the Disability Act. It is also important to point out the Ombudsman has called for revision of the Act
column4: as has the Disability Federation of Ireland. The basic issue is it does not work for people with disabilities. It was enacted in 2005
column5: which means it was developed several years before then and
column6: of course
column7: the most significant legislation
column8: that is
column9: the UNCRPD
column10: came into effect in 2006. The Act predates that and in 2018 Ireland ratified the UNCRPD
column11: which means we are obliged by international law to abide by it and the Disability Act does not allow us to. It certainly is not a matter of the HSE running away from things
column12: rather we it to be aligned to allow us to better deliver on services. One of the ways of doing that is to ensure when we are revising the EPSEN Act
column13: we are also revising an interlocking Act because especially around assessment of needs there are obligations from health services and education services and that has not been working. This is a real opportunity to try to make it work. On training
column14: one of the things we have previously advocated for
column15: especially with some of the new technological universities that have not been doing professional training in health and social professions
column16: is that there be some exciting opportunities to establish new courses where people could all train together in an interdisciplinary way. They could be located in geographical areas where it is perhaps more difficult to retain staff
column17: because all the research evidence shows that when people are trained in particular locations
column19: they are much more likely to stay in those areas.

column1: #MichealCarrigy	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-party	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-dob	unknown-#MichealCarrigy-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	212	I have one more thing to mention before I let Deputy Ó Murchú in. Maybe an autism support worker could give those family courses rather than the professionals because we are stretched already. That needs to be examined. There is one minute left for the Deputy.

#RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	213	I agree. On some level we need something universal across all Departments so we can facilitate children and citizens as they operate in society like the rest of us and not as a failing. Some of the difficulties with the school inclusion model have been thrown up by everybody. Training for teachers is absolutely necessary but there needs to a particular emphasis on resource teachers and even beyond that
column2: SNAs. I know from my own experience that probably made up for an awful lot of services that did not necessary happen for our Turlough and I put that on record. It was said earlier that everyone should work together
column3: such as the CDNTs
column4: the CAMHS and so on. I have an issue with a young girl being referred by the CDNT into the CAMHS for anxiety and probably issues stemming from Covid
column5: which exacerbated things. The response was the service does not deal with kids that are autistic. That is a situation we need to deal with. I get that these services are under pressure and to a degree they are probably playing a game of ping-pong but it is not good enough. It needs to be dealt with. Then there are the adult services.

column1: #RuairiOmurchu	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-party	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-dob	unknown-#RuairiOmurchu-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	214	Certain families are missing out on that framework that would provide them with that little bit that can get their loved one through third level education or whatever else that puts them in a different place. column2: but had let it lapse. We got that sorted. He also dropped out of college. I get the great work that is being done by PAs
column3: and there is another issue there with resourcing PAs in third level. However
column4: I am speaking about the need to provide supports for adult services. In some cases we are not talking about huge supports
column5: just a little bit that can help facilitate users. That needs to be done. That was probably longer than a minute.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	220	Ms O'Kelly spoke about integrated working a few minutes ago. #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2022-10-18 00:00:00	Business of Joint Committee	222	I thank the committee. The issues raised here today have been blended with some suggestions and observations on what would work well
